name: Jill Bilcock
description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Jill Bilcock
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film editor, a member of the Australian Screen Editors guild, as well as the American Cinema Editors society, who has edited films such as Romeo + Juliet (1996), Moulin Rouge! (2001) and Road to Perdition (2002).

constellations_primary.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_primary.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

start.title: Muriel's Wedding costumes
start.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
start.brief_description: These bridesmaid dresses from Muriel’s Wedding are worn by Cheryl and Janine, the self-proclaimed ‘ragers’ who can’t hide their inner nastiness beneath all the ruffles and teased hairdos.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

end.title: Dresses worn by Hayley Magnus and Amanda Woodhams in The Dressmaker
end.credit_line: Courtesy The National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
end.brief_description: In The Dressmaker, Nancy Pickett and Prudence Harridiene (Amanda Woodhams and Hayley Magnus) are two of Dungatar’s worst gossips.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: In The Dressmaker, Nancy Pickett and Prudence Harridiene (Amanda Woodhams and Hayley Magnus) are two of Dungatar’s worst gossips. They’re in the grand tradition of snide characters like Chery and Janine from Muriel’s Wedding.

start.title: Muriel's Wedding
start.creator_credit: P.J. Hogan, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Jill Bilcock, Film Victoria, House and Moorhouse Films and Peter Szabo and Associates
start.brief_description: Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and an out of place girl who would give anything to be like her nasty friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

end.title: Muriel's Wedding costumes
end.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
end.brief_description: These bridesmaid dresses from Muriel’s Wedding are worn by Cheryl and Janine, the self-proclaimed ‘ragers’ who can’t hide their inner nastiness beneath all the ruffles and teased hairdos.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: Like editing, costume design sometimes goes unnoticed by audiences but it crucial to telling stories on screen. The bridesmaid dresses worn by Cheryl (Roz Hammond) and Janine (Belinda Jarrett) unpick their characters, stich by stich.

start.title: Spotlights: Jill Bilcock
start.brief_description: An Australian film editor, a member of the Australian Screen Editors guild, as well as the American Cinema Editors society, who has edited films such as Romeo + Juliet (1996), Moulin Rouge! (2001) and Road to Perdition (2002).

constellations_primary.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_primary.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: After working with filmmaker Richard Lowenstein on her first feature, Strikebound (1984), the two collaborated on the cult Melbourne movie, Dogs in Space. Starring INXS frontman Michael Hutchence, the film exposed sex, drugs and rock n roll in the late 1970s post-punk scene.

start.title: Dogs in Space
start.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: A Country Practice
end.brief_description: A Country Practice was a beloved Australian television drama series that was one of the longest-running dramas of its kind at the time.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor Gary Foley was in Dogs in Space, but he’s got a number of screen credits, including A Country Practice. Foley helped shape the storylines of his character and used the show to bring broader attention to Indigenous issues.

start.title: Dogs in Space
start.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

end.title: Strictly Ballroom
end.creator_credit: Baz Luhrmann, Tristram Miall and New South Wales Film & Television Office
end.brief_description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the establishment by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

links.description: In her first collaboration with Baz Luhrmann, Jill Bilcock won an AACTA for Best Editing when she brought the frenetic, energetic world of ballroom dancing to life in Strictly Ballroom. Bilcock later then worked on Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge!.

start.title: Strictly Ballroom

start.brief_description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the establishment by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps.

end.brief_description: Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and an out of place girl who would give anything to be like her nasty friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: Doubtful anyone told Bilcock she was terrible when editing PJ Hogan’s iconic comedy, Muriel’s Wedding. It was her fourth AACTA nomination for Best Editing. To date, she has 11 nominations and four wins.

start.title: Muriel's Wedding
start.creator_credit: P.J. Hogan, Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House, Jill Bilcock, Film Victoria, House and Moorhouse Films and Peter Szabo and Associates
start.brief_description: Muriel is a dag, an Abba maniac and an out of place girl who would give anything to be like her nasty friends. In her hunt to find Mr. Right in all the wrong places, Muriel takes a one-way ticket to freedom to find herself.

end.title: Ride Like a Girl
end.creator_credit: Rachel Griffiths, Richard Keddie, Enbankment Films, Andrew Knight and Elise McCredie
end.brief_description: The story of Michelle Payne, the first female jockey to win the Melbourne Cup.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: Rachel Griffiths starred alongside Toni Colette as fellow ABBA tragic and outcast Rhonda Epinstall. Twenty-five years after making her big-screen debut, Griffiths made her directorial debut with Ride Like a Girl, which, you guessed it, Bilcock edited.

start.title: Strictly Ballroom
start.creator_credit: Baz Luhrmann, Tristram Miall and New South Wales Film & Television Office
start.brief_description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the establishment by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps.

constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

end.title: Moulin Rouge!
end.creator_credit: Baz Luhrmann, Catherine Knapman, Catherine Martin, Fred Baron, Martin Brown, Philip Martin Brown and Steve E. Andrews
end.headline_credit: Australia and United States of America, 2001
end.brief_description: A celebration of love and creative inspiration takes place in the infamous, gaudy and glamorous Parisian nightclub, at the cusp of the 20th century. A young poet, who is plunged into the heady world of Moulin Rouge, begins a passionate affair with the club’s most notorious and beautiful star.

constellations_other.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_other.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

constellations_other.name: Oscar-winning transformations and prosthetics
constellations_other.description: This Constellation explores how craft help actors undergo award-winning transformations into iconic characters.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Diamonds are still a girl's best friend
constellations_other.description: This constellation explores the continuing cultural impact of Marylin Monroe’s iconic performance of 'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend' in Gentlemen prefer Blondes (1953).

links.description: While Strictly Ballroom won Bilcock’s an AACTA, it was also nominated for an Oscar and was voted as the 32nd best-edited film of all time by the Motion Picture Editors Guild – no surprise considering all the leg kicks, skirt twirls and songs.
